intro: Dichanthelium acuminatum subsp. sericeum, commonly known as silky fingergrass, is a grass species native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its slender, erect stems and narrow, linear leaves with a distinctive silvery sheen. The plant produces small, spikelet-based inflorescences, which are typical of the grass family Poaceae. Its leaves are often covered in fine, silky hairs, giving it its common name. This species is adapted to a variety of soil types and is often found in open habitats such as prairies and disturbed areas.
